div.head: COLONIAL SOCIETY.
div.p:
The following communication was resolved upon at a spe-
cial meeting of the Colonial Society, convened to congratu-
late that distinguished philosopher, the Baron de Humboldt,
upon his arrival in England, and to elect him an honorary
member of the society:—

body.p:
“Sir—The committee of the Colonial Society, in con-
formity with a resolution unanimously adopted this day, beg
leave to express their gratification at your visit to this coun-
try, in the suite of your distinguished Sovereign.

“Identified as the Colonial Society is with the extension
of civilisation, and the development of the internal re-
sources of distant and imperfectly known foreign regions,
the society gladly avails itself of the present opportunity to
tender its respectful congratulations to a philosopher, whose
invaluable services in the cause of geographical discovery
and humanity are acknowledged and justly appreciated by
all civilised nations, for they have had for their special ob-
ject the welfare and advancement of mankind.

“Understanding that your sojourn in England is neces-
sarily brief, the society is obliged to refrain from tendering
at present any other mark of their sincere esteem, than that
of naming you an honorary member of their body, and in
doing so they would beg to offer their heartfelt wishes for
your continued health and happiness.
body.closer:
—By order of the com-
mittee, “Julius Le Souef, Sec.
“The Baron de Humboldt, &c.”

div.p: Baron von Humboldt returned the following answer: —

body.p:
“Monsieur,—Dans la vie agiteéagitée que nous ménons pendant
le trop court séjour de mon Souverain en Angleterre, il ne
me reste que le regret de ne pas avoir un moment de libre pour
exprimer personellement au Comité de l’illustre “Colonial
Society” la vive reconnaissance dont je me sens pénétré.
Je vous supplie, Monsieur, de vouloir bien être l’interpréte
de mes sentimens respectueux. Rien ne pourrait être plus
flatteur pour moi que l’intérêt que mes faibles efforts ont
pu inspirer à une réunion dont les travaux tendent à un
qutbut si noble et si bienfaisant pour l’humanité.
body.closer:
“Agréez, MoesieurMonsieur, je vous supplie, l’homage de la haute
considération avec laquelle j’ai l’honneur d’être,—Mon-
sieur, votre très humble et très obéissant serviteur,
“Le Bn. de Humboldt.
“Monsr. Julius Le Souef, &c.”
